# Background

##
::: {.absolute left="0%" top="50%" width="100%" style="text-align: left; font-style: italic;"}
Our goal at the BrainGlobe Initiative is to accelerate progress in neuroscience by providing a set of interoperable tools -- and building a community -- for computational neuroanatomy.
:::

## Serial two-photon tomography {background-color="black"}

![](img/TV-demo-reencoded.mp4){.fragment .absolute top="15%" left="35%" width=65% loop="true" controls="true" muted="true"}

![](img/microscopy_stpt.png){.absolute top="24%" left="0%" width="30%"}

::: footer
[Osten, P. , Margrie, T. W. (2013) “Mapping brain circuitry with a light microscope” Nature Methods 10, 515–523](https://doi.org/10.1038/nmeth.2477)
:::

::: {.notes}
- Whole brain imaging was becoming more accessible, focus on LSFM vs SSTP
- https://www.nature.com/articles/nmeth.1854
- Moving from single sections to large 3D datasets
- Whole brain microscopy (serial 2p, LSFM) etc becoming very popular
- Need specific tools for large datasets, registration, cell detection etc
  - Require efficient processing of large datasets, but also specific analysis requirements (cell detection etc) and “anatomical context” i.e. registration
- Imaging should feel accessible
:::

## What was needed?
::: {.columns}
::: {.column .fragment fragment-index=2 style="font-size: 0.9em;"}
A platform that enabled the community to:

:::{.incremental}
1. Build tools for whole-brain microscopy data analysis.
2. Work with multiple species and atlases.
3. Interoperate with each other.
:::
